p: The lower respiratory tract and lungs were traditionally believed to be sterile and free from bacteria. However, it is now widely accepted that the lungs are constantly exposed to diverse communities of bacteria from the upper respiratory tract and this has been confirmed with the use of culture-independent techniques such as the 16S rRNA gene sequencing. In one of the first studies in the field, Hilty et al . challenged the dogma that the lower respiratory tract is sterile by showing that bronchial tree contains a characteristic microbial flora that differs between health and disease [ 75].
